TECH SUPPORT IS HERE FOR YOU! Middle and high school students: In-person support for “critical technical issues” is available at your assigned school. Elementary or preschool students: In-person support for “critical technical issues” is available at the high school closest to you.

There is similar support available at those locations for any student who still needs to be assigned an HCPS-issued device, or needs to pick up a WiFi hotspot, while supplies last.

Hours of support are 8 a.m. - 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday.

Read this for specific details: https://henricoschools.us/mobile-technology-hubs/

post_text:
A few first-week photos at the Advanced Career Education (ACE) Center at Highland Springs! A big thank you for all the patience, hard work and planning by our families, students, teachers and staff as we embark on this unusual journey.

Some teachers at the ACE Center were teaching from home, others were teaching from classrooms, but all were eager to get started with their students. Gradually, some small groups will meet in person, depending on the requirements of each class.
text:
A few first-week photos at the Advanced Career Education (ACE) Center at Highland Springs! A big thank you for all the patience, hard work and planning by our families, students, teachers and staff as we embark on this unusual journey.

Some teachers at the ACE Center were teaching from home, others were teaching from classrooms, but all were eager to get started with their students. Gradually, some small groups will meet in person, depending on the requirements of each class.

post_text: A few photos from first-day classes at Deep Run High School. We couldn’t be prouder of the HCPS community in pulling together to launch a new and unprecedented year. The school was one of Superintendent Amy Cashwell’s stops around Henrico to say “thanks” and “welcome” to teachers, students and staff members. School Nutrition Services staff members were preparing for school meals to go out to students (https://henricoschools.us/2020/09/04/hcps-will-provide-students-with-free-meals-in-2-ways-school-curbside-service-and-neighborhood-bus-drop-offs/) and other people were having critical technology issues addressed.

post_text:
Henrico County Government is looking for volunteers to help distribute COVID care kits this Thursday and Friday! It's a partnership with the Virginia Department of Emergency Management Training and the Office of Health Equity under Virginia Department of Health to deliver personal protective equipment and COVID-19 health information to residents in targeted neighborhoods throughout the county.

Volunteers will distribute reusable cloth face coverings, bottles of hand sanitizer and informational materials packed in care kits. Click on the links below to sign up:
Thurs., Aug. 27: https://bit.ly/3aEqFMN
Fri., Aug. 28: https://bit.ly/34sd0Yj

More details are available from Henrico News: http://ow.ly/a29f50B9ySq

post_text:
HCPS is making sure every student at every school has a touchscreen tablet, a Chromebook or a laptop! Check out these highlights from our recent laptop distribution...and there's more to come (specific instructions are being communicated by your school, so please check your messages!):

Aug. 17-20: Distribution of Chromebooks to elementary school students. Rising first-graders will receive Chromebooks, as will all other students in grades 2-5 who still need one.

Aug. 24-28: Distribution of iPads to pre-K and K students. Preschool and kindergarten students will pick up iPads (and in some cases exchange their Chromebooks issued in the spring).

Aug. 31-Sept. 4: Remote technology hubs open at all secondary schools. Hubs will be open at all HCPS middle and high schools to complete device distribution (including devices for newly enrolled high school students) and support other student and staff technology issues.
text:
HCPS is making sure every student at every school has a touchscreen tablet, a Chromebook or a laptop! Check out these highlights from our recent laptop distribution...and there's more to come (specific instructions are being communicated by your school, so please check your messages!):

Aug. 17-20: Distribution of Chromebooks to elementary school students. Rising first-graders will receive Chromebooks, as will all other students in grades 2-5 who still need one.

Aug. 24-28: Distribution of iPads to pre-K and K students. Preschool and kindergarten students will pick up iPads (and in some cases exchange their Chromebooks issued in the spring).

Aug. 31-Sept. 4: Remote technology hubs open at all secondary schools. Hubs will be open at all HCPS middle and high schools to complete device distribution (including devices for newly enrolled high school students) and support other student and staff technology issues.

post_text:
MEAL SERVICE UPDATE: Due to the temporary closure of Varina High School, the “grab and go meal service” that typically takes place at Varina High School will move to Rolfe Middle School, located at 6901 Messer Rd. (next to Varina High School).

“Grab and go meal service” will be available at Rolfe Middle School today (Thursday, Aug. 13) and Monday, Aug. 17, from 11 a.m. until Noon. Students can receive meals for the weekend at today’s pickup.

For the full list of “grab and go meal service” sites, visit this page: https://henricoschools.us/covid19/grab-and-go-breakfasts-and-lunches/
text:
MEAL SERVICE UPDATE: Due to the temporary closure of Varina High School, the “grab and go meal service” that typically takes place at Varina High School will move to Rolfe Middle School, located at 6901 Messer Rd. (next to Varina High School).

“Grab and go meal service” will be available at Rolfe Middle School today (Thursday, Aug. 13) and Monday, Aug. 17, from 11 a.m. until Noon. Students can receive meals for the weekend at today’s pickup.

For the full list of “grab and go meal service” sites, visit this page: https://henricoschools.us/covid19/grab-and-go-breakfasts-and-lunches/

post_text:
NEW: “A day in the life” for elementary school students! This video was made for families of elementary school students to help show what predominantly virtual learning will look like for grades K-5.

This video, along with our detailed “Learning Plan: A Handbook for Families and Students”, will be presented to the Henrico School Board on Thursday. For more information (and to flip through our handbook once it’s released) stay close to your email this week, or visit us on this page: https://henricoschools.us/returntoschool/

Thanks to our teachers as well as our students whose families gave permission to participate! (Some names were changed or blurred for privacy.)

Also of note:

Elementary schools are communicating instructions for Chromebook pickup, which takes place the week of Aug. 17 (for grades 1-5), and iPad pickup, which takes place the week of Aug. 23 (for pre-K & Kindergarten).

Elementary schools will communicate their “master schedules” on Thursday, Aug. 13.

Elementary school teacher assignments will come out the week of Aug. 17.

post_text:
Because of the forecast associated with Tropical Storm Isaias, HCPS school and office buildings will be closed on Tuesday, Aug. 4. However, school system business may still be conducted through teleworking and other virtual arrangements. Schools will work to reschedule in-person appointments that were expected to take place on Tuesday.

(Debido al pronóstico del tiempo de mañana asociado con la tormenta tropical Isaías, los edificios escolares y de oficinas de HCPS estarán cerradas el martes 4 de agosto. Sin embargo, el sistema escolar aún funcionará por teletrabajo y otras formas virtuales. Las escuelas trabajarán para reprogramar las citas en persona que se esperaban que tengan lugar el martes.)

post_text:
We've posted a new collection of answers to frequently asked questions about the plan to begin the 2020-21 school year. HCPS will use a predominantly virtual format for at least the first nine weeks. The updated information is geared primarily to families and can be found by going to https://henricoschools.us/returntoschool/faq/. It is also being emailed to HCPS families and employees.

The FAQs include new or updated information about a variety of topics, including:
- Key definitions.
- Support for working families.
- Technology for students, including iPads, Chromebooks and Dell laptops.
- Special education and individualized education programs.
- Support for students who are English learners.
- Student transportation for limited, in-person learning.

New information will be added to the Mission Forward return-to-school webpage as it becomes available. The page is at https://henricoschools.us/returntoschool/.

post_text:
HCPS will be represented at Saturday’s “Students for a Change” event, including Roscoe Cooper, chair of the Henrico School Board (and Fairfield District representative) and Alicia Atkins, the School Board’s Varina District representative!

Mrs. Atkins said, “There is significant outreach from families and students about reopening of school, affordable childcare, racial discrimination, and resources in the East End. Recognizing that our community cares deeply about these topics, I am excited about participating in Students for a Change event. This free community event is Saturday, Aug. 1, on the lawn at the Eastern Henrico Recreation Center (1440 N. Laburnum Ave, Richmond, VA 23223) from 10 a.m. - 1 p.m. This is a wonderful way for leaders and students to share their thoughts and solutions on these topics.”

These speeches have us fired up! "We need to come together, and we need to do it for our kids." "We heard you. We've talked to you. We've read everything. We've listened." "The goal of every single person in this room is to get our kids back to school. And to do that we need our community's help." "We have to embrace change with a positive outlook and work to resolve challenges."

Watch, as our School Board members share their thoughts and feelings prior to Thursday's vote for a virtual start to the 2020-21 school year...

A big shout-out to robotics students at Mills Godwin High School! Members of TALON 540, the school's FIRST Robotics team (the acronym means "For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology") launched the inaugural issue of a new digital magazine, the "TALON Tabloid." The magazine will deal with the STEAM concepts of science, technology, engineering, the arts and math. Way to go, TALON 540 Eagles!

Read the whole digital issue here: https://www.team540.com/talon-tabloid.

post_text:
Come to a "Thank you, retirees!" virtual watch party!

Henrico County Public Schools is lucky to have one of the most talented, caring and hardworking education teams in the U.S. When our friends and colleagues retire, it's bittersweet: we're grateful for their work for Henrico families, and happy for what lies ahead for them — but it's hard to lose all those years of expertise (and friendship).

Watch Tuesday at 6:30 p.m. as HCPS recognizes 181 retiring employees with a combined 3,922 years of service! You can see the virtual ceremony via livestream at henricoschools.us, on our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/HenricoCountyPublicSchools/ or watch on our cable channel, HCPS-TV on Comcast channel 99 and Verizon channel 38.

post_text:
A message from Douglas S. Freeman High School about this evening’s “Freeman Family Forum” (Tuesday, July 14):

“Freeman High School has asked the community to provide feedback on whether the ‘Rebels’ mascot and nickname matches the school’s core values. DSF has discovered that ‘Rebels’ means different things to individuals in our community as this conversation is taking place all around the Freeman Family. To reflect that conversation, DSF is holding a Freeman Family Forum, a panel discussion, on Tuesday, July 14th at 6 p.m.

Six members of the Freeman community, whose experiences and views span the continuum on this issue, will discuss what the mascot has meant to them.

On Tuesday (today) at 6 p.m., visit www.freemanmascot.info to view the livestream of this Zoom conversation and to submit your own questions to the moderators.”

post_text:
Was your child enrolled in HCPS' early learning preschool program in 2019-20? Pick up books this week to help them revisit skills from the school year and prepare for kindergarten in the fall!

Summer books for your child will be available for pickup July 6-8 (tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday) at New Bridge Learning Center, 5915 Nine Mile Road in eastern Henrico. The books correspond to lessons in the upcoming Season 3 of "Henrico Edflix," HCPS' summer virtual learning program.

All HCPS preschool students can participate in Season 3 of Henrico Edflix, which is available July 13 - Aug. 6. No sign-up is required. Starting Monday, July 13, go to http://blogs.henrico.k12.va.us/hlp/virtual-learning/ and get started.

Preschool books pickup:
Where: New Bridge Learning Center, 5915 Nine Mile Road, Henrico, Va.

- July 6, 9 a.m. to noon
- July 7, 9 a.m. to noon
- July 8, 1-4 p.m.

post_text:
“Grab and Go” meal distribution sites will be closed this Thursday and Friday for observance of Independence Day. On Wednesday, July 1, families can visit any of our “Grab and Go” meal sites and pick up breakfasts and lunches for Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Normal “Grab and Go” meal distribution will resume Monday, July 6 from 11 a.m. until noon, Monday through Thursday.

Our four mobile technology hubs will also be closed for the holiday observance. Tech hubs will be open for laptop repairs and other technology issues on Wednesday, July 1 and will reopen Monday, July 6 from 8:30-10:30 a.m.

The HCPS “hotline” at 804-501-5655 will be closed Thursday and Friday. Operators will be resume normal summer hours on Monday, July 6 from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m., Monday through Thursday.
text:
“Grab and Go” meal distribution sites will be closed this Thursday and Friday for observance of Independence Day. On Wednesday, July 1, families can visit any of our “Grab and Go” meal sites and pick up breakfasts and lunches for Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Normal “Grab and Go” meal distribution will resume Monday, July 6 from 11 a.m. until noon, Monday through Thursday.

Our four mobile technology hubs will also be closed for the holiday observance. Tech hubs will be open for laptop repairs and other technology issues on Wednesday, July 1 and will reopen Monday, July 6 from 8:30-10:30 a.m.

The HCPS “hotline” at 804-501-5655 will be closed Thursday and Friday. Operators will be resume normal summer hours on Monday, July 6 from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m., Monday through Thursday.

post_text:
"What she tackles, she conquers." What a joy it was to watch this moment from Godwin High School senior Maggie Rocke, who had a goal since the beginning of high school to walk across the graduation stage to receive her diploma.

Her physical therapist, Laura Fultz, told us earlier this year that Maggie has worked so hard from early in her school career overcoming many obstacles associated with cerebral palsy. “Unfortunately without the Seigel Center crowd she was expecting, this COVID-19 closure has taken that public opportunity from her, and we [wanted] to make it up to her somehow! She has continued to work hard practicing and improving her physical strength during the closure and is planning to walk to receive her diploma.”

At long last, cameras were rolling as Maggie received her diploma in a joyous individual ceremony that took place Tuesday at the school.

Maggie said, “It’s a little surreal.” “I know, but you did it,” replied Laura.

Congratulations, Maggie!

post_text:
Don’t forget to tune in tonight (Tuesday) starting at 6 p.m. for “Community Conversations: Student Voices”, an online panel of HCPS high school students as they discuss issues of racism, injustice and inequity. The conversations are part of HCPS’ Family Learning Series workshops.

For details and information about how to easily join the discussion using Google Meet, go to https://henricoschools.us/family-learning-series/. No registration is required. Only the first 250 virtual attendees will be able to participate and comment during the discussion. If the audience is larger than 250, those participants will be able to see and hear the discussion using a livestream link that will appear on the Family Learning Series page. The session will also be recorded and posted online for additional viewing.

post_text:
REMINDERS & MEAL SERVICE FOR THURSDAY, 6/18: This coming Monday, HCPS offices will be closed, in observance of the Juneteenth holiday, an important step in our efforts to encourage discussion, reflection and awareness of Black culture and historical legacies that have been marginalized for far too long. Since HCPS facilities are already closed Fridays as we start our summer schedule, students who take part in our summer meals service should plan to come today (Thursday) and pick up additional meals for this Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday.

Las oficinas estarán cerradas el lunes. Los estudiantes que participan en nuestro servicio de comidas de verano deben planear venir mañana (jueves) para recoger las comidas los jueves, viernes, sábado y domingo.

The HCPS hotline (804-501-5655) for questions and concerns related to COVID-19 will also be closed on Monday.

post_text: Starting today (Monday), HCPS ‘grab and go’ sites will operate Monday through Thursday, in accordance with HCPS’ traditional summer schedule. The curbside distribution sites are open 11 a.m. until noon. On Thursdays, students, parents and guardians can also pick up meals for Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. Distribution is on a first-come, first-served basis and is open to all students, regardless of what school they attend, as well as others age 18 and under.

post_text:
WATCHING THE WEATHER: A "heads up" message for the Glen Allen, Hermitage, and Tucker High School seniors:

Thursday is your “Victory Lap” at Richmond Raceway, and there are strong to severe storms in the weather forecast. Right now, there are no changes to announce, but we want you to stay close to your phone, email, our website and social media in case we have to announce any changes. We’re keeping an eye on the weather forecast tonight, and we will wait until tomorrow morning to make final decisions.

Potential changes could involve the possibility of delaying one or more of the Victory Laps, or, postponing one or more of them until the rain date of Saturday, June 13.

We will follow up with you on Thursday around 8 a.m. to let you know if there are any changes.

Thank you for reading, and congratulations to the Class of 2020!

post_text:
Congratulations to the graduates of Henrico County-St. Mary's School of Practical Nursing! Members of the Class of 2020 celebrated their commencement with safety in mind, taking advantage of the hospitality of Henrico Fire Station 3 in Highland Springs to conduct a "drive-thru commencement."

The nursing program, a joint venture of Henrico County Public Schools and Bon Secours St. Mary’s Hospital, was tabbed by PracticalNursing.org as Virginia’s No. 3 program for licensed practical nurses. Nursing Schools Almanac named the school the commonwealth’s No. 6 program for licensed practical nurses in 2020, and Virginia’s No. 26-ranked program overall.

Check it out! That's Kennedy George on the left, and her friend Ava Holloway. Kennedy is a rising 9th grader headed to the Henrico High School Center for the Arts, and recently graduated from Fairfield Middle School's International Baccalaureate Program (Ava attends school not far from Henrico). Her mother, Chris, is part of our School Based Mental Health Services team, and she told us, "We are so very proud of them as their photos have gone viral, being posted and shared by social activists as well as many celebrities!"

Thanks to ABC 8News - WRIC for the story!

Congratulations go out to Echo Lake Elementary’s Erin Franklin, the 2020 HCPS Music Educator of the Year! Mrs. Franklin, a 1999 J.R. Tucker High School graduate, has been teaching in Henrico for more than 16 years; 11 of which have been at ELES. Previously, Mrs. Franklin was named Teacher of the Year for Pinchbeck Elementary in 2010 and Teacher of the Year for Echo Lake Elementary in 2014. She’s been a National Board-Certified teacher in Early-Middle Childhood Music since 2012!

Congratulations Erin!

post_text:
Serving as an active participant in a larger society is the basis of what it means to be a Global Citizen. London Hart, a seventh-grader at Moody Middle School, found a way to give back to the community she loves through art, entrepreneurship and T-shirts!

London became inspired by current events and created original art to make t-shirts to raise money for local causes. In just over a day, London’s “Support Shirts Fundraiser” sold more than 200 shirts! All proceeds will be donated to causes affiliated with the Black Lives Matter movement (so far, that’s $870!). She asked us, “I was wondering if you may be able to help share my story so I can encourage other kids and adults to fight racism together.”

London, consider it done. Thank you for sharing your story with us and embodying what it means to be a Global Citizen!

post_text:
Let's give it up for this year's HCPS Teacher Scholars!

This year there are six recipients who will complete their teacher education programs in college, and then return to HCPS where there will be a guaranteed teaching position waiting for them! Join us in congratulating: Carlos Alarcon (Highland Springs HS); Justina Brookman (Mills Godwin HS); Madison Glattfelder-Quizoa (Mills Godwin HS); Jordan Johnson (Glen Allen HS); Makayla Lewis (Mills Godwin HS); and Kasie Parrott (Mills Godwin HS).

The HCPS Teacher Scholars program for high school seniors was implemented to address staffing needs and the increasing demand for highly qualified teachers in critical shortage teaching areas, through a "homegrown" approach. It is designed to improve the delivery of service to HCPS students. Content areas are Spanish, mathematics, exceptional education, earth and physical science, technology education, and family and consumer sciences.

Congratulations all! We look forward to working with you in the 2024-25 school year!

shared_text:
Henrico County Government
May 27 at 2:36 PM ·

Henrico will distribute “care kits” with reusable face coverings and information about COVID-19 to homes in the county’s western area Saturday to help residents protect themselves during the pandemic.

As they did last week in the county's central and eastern areas, volunteers will walk door to door, leaving kits at homes while avoiding contact with residents as a safety precaution. Each kit will include a sealable bag with three face coverings and flyers with information about the 2020 Census and COVID-19.

Volunteers are needed for Saturday's outreach. For information and to register, go to handsonrva.org/opportunity/a0C1J00000J4QJC?Id=a0C1J00000J4QJC

Volunteers also are needed to assemble kits from 2 to 5 p.m. tomorrow and Friday. For information and to register, handsonrva.org/opportunity/a0C1J00000J4Rro?Id=a0C1J00000J4Rro.

henrico.us/news/2020/05/henrico-to-distribute-more-covid-19-care-kits-saturday/

post_text:
Thanks to @childrensmuseumofrichmond and to its donors for giving more than 2,000 books for HCPS students in pre-K through grade 8! The donations come from the museum's "Children's Book Bank." The Book Bank collects new or like-new books for area students. (Find out more at https://www.childrensmuseumofrichmond.org/community/book-bank/. The banks are not accepting donations while the museum is closed to combat coronavirus.)

The HCPS Library Services Department will make sure these books get into the hands of our learners in various ways throughout the summer, including placing books in our free "book nook" mini-libraries in front of all of HCPS' schools.

post_text:
Please take a short survey and tell us what you think of the two calendar options for the 2021-2022 school year. They are:

● Calendar Option A (pre-Labor Day start.) School would begin on Monday, Aug. 23, 2021. School would end on Friday, June 3, 2022.
● Calendar Option B (traditional post-Labor Day start.) School would begin on Wednesday, Sept. 8, 2021. School would end on Friday, June 17, 2022.

Reminder: The 2020-21 school year is already scheduled to begin on the day after Labor Day, which is Tuesday, Sept. 8, 2020. This message and survey are about the school year that begins in the year 2021. The survey is available by going to HCPS’ website, henricoschools.us, and looking under “Hot Topics,” or by going to https://henricoschools.us/2021-22-calendar-options/.

The survey closes Wednesday, June 3 at 8 a.m.

Henrico will distribute reusable face coverings and flyers with information about COVID-19 to nearly 15,000 homes in the county’s central and eastern areas on Saturday. post_text:
“Grab and Go” meal distribution sites will be closed on Memorial Day. On Friday, May 22, families can visit any of our “Grab and Go” meal sites and pick up breakfasts and lunches for Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday. Normal “Grab and Go” meal distribution will resume on Tuesday, May 26 from 11 a.m. until Noon each weekday.

Our four mobile technology hubs will also be closed on Memorial Day. Tech hubs will be open for laptop repairs and other technology issues on Friday, May 22, and reopen on Tuesday, May 26 from 8:30-10:30 a.m. and 2-4 p.m. each weekday.

The HCPS “hotline” at (804) 501-5655 will be closed this Saturday, Sunday and Monday. Operators will be available on Friday, May 22, and resume normal hours on Tuesday, May 26, from 8 a.m. until 4:30 p.m. seven days a week.

The technology “Help Desk” number of (804) 328-5207 will also be closed this Saturday, Sunday and Monday.

More details: https://henricoschools.us/covid19/

post_text:
Congratulations go out to Gabe Griffin, a 9th grader from Godwin High School, on being named Virginia’s Champion and selected to compete in Certiport’s Microsoft Office Specialist U.S. National Championship!

The Microsoft Office Specialist U.S. National Championship presented by Certiport, Inc. is a competition that tests students’ skills on Microsoft Office Word, Excel® and PowerPoint® (2016 or 2019). Top students are invited to represent their respective states at the U.S. National Championship. The 2021 Microsoft Office Specialist U.S. National Championship is scheduled to take place in Florida next summer.

Congratulations Gabe! We look forward to hearing all about the competition next year!

post_text:
Congratulations to L. Douglas Wilder Middle School’s Dorota Ceglarz, this year’s Christie Award Winner for Exceptional Education Teacher of the Year! Dorota was surprised with the news by Superintendent Amy Cashwell and School Board Chair Roscoe Cooper during a virtual staff meeting last week.

The Christie Award annually recognizes a member of the Exceptional Education team whose contribution to HCPS has been exemplary in the service to children with disabilities and their families. This award is named in honor of Christie Ann Heatwole, daughter of Evelyn and Ray Heatwole, whose life characterized the passion and enthusiasm central to our mission of serving all students.

Colleagues shared that Dorota is a continuous learner, builds meaningful relationships with students and families, and is driven by what is BEST for students.

Dorota, we thank you for your commitment and service to our students and their families!

The Christie Award annually recognizes a member of the Exceptional Education team whose contribution to HCPS has been exemplary in the service to children with disabilities and their families. This award is named in honor of Christie Ann Heatwole, daughter of Evelyn and Ray Heatwole, whose life characterized the passion and enthusiasm central to our mission of serving all students.

Colleagues shared that Dorota is a continuous learner, builds meaningful relationships with students and families, and is driven by what is BEST for students.

Dorota, we thank you for your commitment and service to our students and their families!

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating Clara Smith from Kaechele Elementary and Joshua Flemings from Jackson Davis Elementary on winning the Papa John’s Better Future Fund Award!

The Better Future Fund is a program that recognizes a student who has a passion for improving their community. Students had to submit a written essay describing how they would better their community if they were to attend a college or secondary education. Of all the entries submitted from Central Virginia schools, only five students were selected to receive this award. This year Henrico County had two winners!

Congrats Clara and Joshua!

post_text:
Next time you’re inside Central Office or New Bridge Learning Center (and it may take some time for that to happen!), be sure to check out the walls — they’re graced with award-winning artwork from HCPS students.

Each year, in conjunction with Youth Art Month, each HCPS art teacher selects a student work to be displayed in the Annual School Board Exhibit. The framed works will hang in the New Bridge Learning Center auditorium or Central Office building for one year. These works of art are beautiful examples of student creativity, craftsmanship and hard work.

The winners were photographed back in early March with the School Board (prior to "virtual meetings"), holding their winning certificates. Congrats, students!

May 15 at 3:13 PM ·

HEF is expanding the impact of its COVID-19 Response Fund supporting vulnerable children and families in Henrico County, thanks to a $280,000 grant from Facebook. post_text:
UPDATE on the 2021-22 Henrico County Public Schools Calendar: We know the school calendar options for 2021-22 were of significant interest on social media this week. At today's work session, the School Board discussed the matter at length and directed HCPS staff to take the idea of "extended school year" (also known as "year-round school") off the table.

Next week, HCPS employees and our parent community can expect to receive a survey and additional information on two options: Starting school BEFORE Labor Day, or, AFTER Labor Day in the year 2021. Stay tuned next week for additional information and opportunities to share your feedback.

(As a reminder, the 2020-21 school year is already scheduled to start on Tuesday, Sept. 8, 2020. This post is about the school year that begins in the year 2021.)

post_text:
NEW signs are going up on our school playgrounds and other areas this week indicating what is again open for use! Generally, you will see these signs on or around school playgrounds, ball fields, basketball courts and tennis courts:

"NOTICE: This area is open for use.

However, please note that these surfaces cannot be sanitized regularly, and the coronavirus can survive on metal and plastic surfaces for up to three days. Groups of more than 10 are still prohibited under executive order of the governor.

Please continue to follow CDC guidelines, practice social distancing while on school grounds, and wash your hands frequently.

Be responsible, stay safe and healthy. Thank you!"

Check out the front page of today's Richmond Times-Dispatch for a tremendous story on Henrico High School's Jasmine Mason, a senior in the Center for the Arts Visual Arts program who has been awarded a Scholastics National Gold Key Portfolio! Not only is this a huge achievement for Jasmine, as only eight students in the country receive this award, but it also a tremendous honor for the CFA Visual Arts program as it is the THIRD time that a CFA student has won this prestigious award!

Way to go Jasmine! And kudos to our CFA Visual Arts teachers, Ms. Scurlock and Mrs. Dowdy!

Story by Bill Lohmann...

post_text:
Let’s give it up for Jontae Burton, a senior at Henrico High School, who was just named a National Semi-Finalist for the U.S. Presidential Scholars Program!

The U.S. Presidential Scholars Program was established in 1964, by executive order of the President, to recognize and honor some of our nation's most distinguished graduating high school seniors. Each year, up to 161 students are named as Presidential Scholars, one of the nation's highest honors for high school students.

Congratulations Jontae!

post_text:
Thank you for your generosity! Nicholas LaGanke, Callan Walsh, Lucy Ferri, Emily Barnes, and Maddie Florence (fifth graders from Kaechele Elementary) were all looking forward to participating in Market Day earlier this year. Market Day is an event where students are divided into groups to make items to “sell” while earning “cash” to purchase items made by other students (in the real Market Day, no actual cash is exchanged.)

Unfortunately, the closure of schools prevented the event from occurring. So the students came up with a new plan for all the items they created. With the assistance of their parents, they decided the sell the items through their community Facebook group and donate the money to the Henrico Education Foundation. Everything sold within a week and more than $200 was collected! The students donated the proceeds to HEF, which will direct the funds to our food service efforts.

Thank you Nicholas, Callan, Lucy, Emily, and Maddie for your community spirit and kindness!

post_text:
Congratulations again to Varina High School's Jessica Orzechowski, the HCPS First-Year Teacher of the Year! Jessica (seen here with her young son and no doubt being honored on this Mother's Day!) received the honor 'virtually' during a staff meeting last week that featured surprise appearances from Varina District School Board Representative Alicia Atkins and Superintendent Amy Cashwell!

“This award means everything to me and my family,” said Orzechowski. “From the moment I stepped onto Varina’s campus, it felt like home — the school’s dedication to professional growth and academic excellence has challenged me in ways I have never been challenged before. The students at Varina are exceptional and I really owe my success to them. They immediately appealed to my Philadelphia roots with their passion and love for their community. They are strong in the face of adversity and will move mountains for you. It is an honor to refer to them as ‘my kids.’ This is as much their award as it is mine and I am so proud to share it with them and my colleagues. Go Blue Devils!”

post_text:
FIVE LITTLE WORDS #4 of 4: What five little words describe our Henrico teachers? We've been proud to share your submissions in four videos that we hope you’ll take a moment to watch. We can all use a pick-me-up at times these days, and we guarantee these sincere words from our school community won’t disappoint.

Scroll back through our feed to see all of our #fivelittlewords videos!

*A note about the videos: While we made every effort to include ALL pictures we received (including those that arrived after last Thursday’s deadline), some pictures just didn’t work. Either the file type was incompatible with our editing software, or there was some other technical issue. If you didn’t see your student’s photo, please know there was nothing intentional about that, and we apologize for the disappointment. Try adding your photo to the comments of our social media posts, or email a new photo to fivelittlewords@henrico.k12.va.us and we’ll think of another way to include it!

Thanks to all who participated!

(This is video #4 of 4)

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating Jack O’Leary, a junior at Deep Run High School and leader of FIRST Robotics Competition team Blue Cheese, on being named a Dean’s List winner at a virtual awards ceremony on Saturday! Jack was one of ten winners worldwide out of 3,000 finalists!

The Dean’s List award is the highest individual honor a student can receive from FIRST, a non-profit organization that promotes STEM engagement through robotics competitions. Jack was nominated for the award by his robotics team, then selected as a Dean’s List finalist from the FIRST Chesapeake District (Virginia, DC & Maryland), and finally announced as a competition winner online Saturday.

For more information on the award visit: https://www.firstinspires.org/resource-library/frc/submitted-awards#deanslist

Congratulations Jack on your achievement!

post_text:
Have a question for HCPS?
Our team is still working remotely, and we’re tuned in to email and voicemail! Many questions about your student can be addressed by our schools, and we suggest you start by contacting your student’s teacher, counselor or principal.

We also have two hotlines to call.
The first is for general questions: call 804-501-5655, seven days a week, 8 a.m.–4:30 p.m.

The second is for student laptop and Chromebook issues: call the “Helpdesk” at 804-328-5207 or email helpdesk@henrico.k12.va.us. Please note that the Helpdesk will only respond to emails and voicemails left on the Helpdesk number M-F during normal business hours. We will do our best to call you back within 24 hours.

We are happy to help you!

The second is for student laptop and Chromebook issues: call the “Helpdesk” at 804-328-5207 or email helpdesk@henrico.k12.va.us. Please note that the Helpdesk will only respond to emails and voicemails left on the Helpdesk number M-F during normal business hours. We will do our best to call you back within 24 hours.

We are happy to help you!

Find out more at https://henricoschools.us/registration/.

ALSO: We expect to have an update on Pre-K registration very soon, too! We look forward to meeting you!

post_text:
Congratulations to Laurel Roeder, reading coach at Arthur Ashe Elementary School, who was recently selected as Virginia's Reading Teacher of the Year! Laurel was recognized as the commonwealth's top reading instructor at a gathering of the Richmond Area Reading Chapter.

With grant money she received as part of her award, Laurel created a “First Readers Club” at Ashe to focus on books and reading. Students in the club have heard a variety of book talks by staff members from local bookstore Bbgb tales for kids. Students got to choose books to donate to the school library in their names. Laurel has served as the Title I reading coach at Arthur Ashe for three years, after serving in the same capacity at Elizabeth Holladay Elementary School.

What makes Laurel such an effective teacher? She is at the forefront of translating research into practice, and this year is seeing unprecedented success using data to find appropriate ways to help her students.

Congratulations to Laurel!

Congratulations to Laurel Roeder, reading coach at Arthur Ashe Elementary School, who was recently selected as Virginia's Reading Teacher of the Year! Laurel was recognized as the commonwealth's top reading instructor at a gathering of the Richmond Area Reading Chapter.

Students in the club have heard a variety of book talks by staff members from local bookstore Bbgb tales for kids. Students got to choose books to donate to the school library in their names. Laurel has served as the Title I reading coach at Arthur Ashe for three years, after serving in the same capacity at Elizabeth Holladay Elementary School.

What makes Laurel such an effective teacher? She is at the forefront of translating research into practice, and this year is seeing unprecedented success using data to find appropriate ways to help her students.

Congratulations to Laurel!

post_text:
CORRECTION: Katie Kier's recent award was for Librarian of the Year for the James Region of the Virginia Association of School Librarians, a region that stretches from Hanover County to the North Carolina border. She and other regional winners will be be considered for the state award, which will be announced in the fall. We apologize for the error. Good luck, Katie!

-------------

We all know HCPS school librarians are the best, and here's more proof! Katie Kier of L. Douglas Wilder Middle School was named the commonwealth's top school librarian by the Virginia Association of School Librarians!

The news was announced to the entire staff at Wilder at a virtual staff meeting.

Katie was described as "an incredible leader and amazing librarian." Last year, she was named one of HCPS' first "School Librarians of the Year."

Congrats to Katie, to LDWMS, and to the HCPS Library Services Department on the 2020 Virginia School Librarian of the Year award — and happy School Library Month!

post_text:
Schools are closed for 2019-20, but HCPS’ ‘Questions’ page will provide the latest updates:

Gov. Northam’s order closing Virginia’s schools for the remainder of the school year raises countless questions for Henrico County Public Schools families and staff members.
As decisions are made or change in the wake of the closure, HCPS will post regular updates to its “Commonly Asked Questions” webpage. The page can be found at henricoschools.us/covid19/commonquestions/ or by going to the school division’s website, henricoschools.us and clicking on the “COVID-19” banner.

Some recent questions addressed on the page include:
• What about graduation?
• Will HCPS employees continue to be paid?
• Will students still take SOL tests?
• How can I help a family in need?
• What about proms?
• What about athletic events, and after-school and weekend activities?

post_text:
On Thursday, March 26 the County School Board of Henrico County, Virginia, will hold the following meeting: Work Session. The meeting will take place at 1 p.m.

Due to the state of emergency regarding COVID-19, there will be no regular monthly meeting for March 2020.

The meeting will take place in the auditorium of the New Bridge Learning Center, 5915 Nine Mile Road, Henrico, Virginia. Closed sessions will be held during the work session as deemed necessary. School Board meetings remain open to the public and interested citizens are invited to attend. However, current health and safety guidelines recommend minimizing large groups of people. With that in mind, we would like to remind you that all School Board work sessions are livestreamed on the main HCPS website, henricoschools.us. We invite you to view the work session via the livestream, as there will be no “Public Forum” in March, due to the cancellation of the regular monthly meeting.

To view “BoardDocs,” where meeting agendas can be found, please click here: http://www.boarddocs.com/vsba/henrico/Board.nsf/Public.

post_text:
Need a laugh and a smile on this Monday morning? Here’s “What Happens To Principals When They Can’t Go To School”, brought to you by the family of Dr. Nic Barlett, principal of Brookland Middle School.

Nic told us, “We wanted to do something to brighten the day of others. One of the silver linings to this has been our ability to slow down enough to do the little things that get lost in the daily hustle. We have seen over and over again how clever people in our community have been with their own contribution to keeping us all connected. This is our little part.”

Enjoy!

Cast:

Nic Barlett (Dr. Daddy): Principal, Brookland Middle School
April Barlett: Art teacher, Greenwood Elementary School
Eli Barlett: 6th grade
Lucas Barlett: 4th grade

By the end of the day well over 100,000 books were checked out! That’s some serious reading taking place!

TUESDAY, WEDNESDAY, THURSDAY, FRIDAY (of this week): Henrico Schools will be distributing free “grab and go” school meals for students! Pick-up hours are scheduled for 11 a.m. to noon, but hours and locations may increase, depending on demand.

The packaged lunches and breakfasts will be available each school day on a first-come, first-served basis. Food distribution is open to all students, regardless of what school they attend, as well as others under age 18. Adults must be accompanied by each child under 18 who needs a meal.

The packaged lunches and breakfasts will be available each school day on a first-come, first-served basis. Food distribution is open to all students, regardless of what school they attend, as well as others under age 18. Adults must be accompanied by each child under 18 who needs a meal.

post_text:
McKenna Masterson and Kiki Spears, students at Pocahontas Middle School, never got to meet Madison Clodius, the fiance of their beloved teacher, Ryan Bierlair, because Madison passed away suddenly due to an epileptic seizure.

Madison and Kiki wanted to do something and made it their mission to learn more about epilepsy and how the central nervous system worked. They could've stopped there, however, they took it one step further and had a bake sale in honor of Madison. They collected over $1,200 and all of the proceeds were donated to the Epilepsy Foundation of Virginia!

Thank you McKenna and Kiki for truly embodying all of the attributes of the Henrico Learner Profile!

Henrico County Public Schools is accepting applications to attend its 2020 Teacher Hiring Event. The March 27 event is geared toward job candidates in the following critical-needs teaching areas:

- Math.
- World languages.
- Science.
- English.
- Career and technical education (CTE).
- Special education.
- School counseling.
- Title-I schools.

To apply, go to henricoschools.us and look under “Hot Topics,” or go to henricoschools.us/careers and click on the application button. The application window closes March 15.

Due to space limitations, teacher attendance at the hiring event will be by invitation only. Should you not be selected to attend, please apply for available teaching vacancies by visiting henricoschools.us/careers/.

Data collected from the U.S. Census not only generates federal funding — it's also used to apportion seats in the U.S. House of Representatives and adjust political district boundaries to ensure residents have equal representation in their state and local governments.

Find out more at https://henrico.us/news/2020/02/be-counted-in-the-2020-census/.

post_text:
Another couple with ties to Henrico Schools is in the running for the Dover Hall Operation "I Do" dream wedding experience!

Not only is Katelyn Gordon a product of Henrico County Public Schools (having attended Glen Allen Elementary, Moody Middle, and Glen Allen High School) but she and her fiance, Michael Patton, are also Henrico County police officers!

To read more about Katelyn and Michael and to cast your vote for any of the finalists please visit: https://www.doverhall.com/operationidovote. Voting concludes March 11, 2020.

Katelyn's sister Stacie tells us, "Michael and Katelyn were supposed to get married back in November, but due to a military obligation they had to cancel the wedding they had planned last minute without reimbursement. It would mean the world to them, and to their families, for them to get a second chance to have their dream wedding!"

Thank you to everyone who pointed out that we have TWO couples with HCPS connections in the running! Good luck to all!

On this Super Tuesday, why not cast your vote for Henry and Callie for Operation "I Do"! Henry (a former HCPS student currently deployed in Kuwait) and Callie (a teacher in the Teach for America program), are among the final contestants in the Dover Hall Operation "I Do" dream wedding experience!

Henry attended Tuckahoe and Nuckols Farm Elementary Schools, Tuckahoe Middle, and Freeman High School where he was one of Freeman's top lacrosse players! His mother, Stephanie, has been teaching in the county for 15 years.

To read more about their love story and to cast your vote please visit: https://www.doverhall.com/operationidovote. Voting concludes March 11, 2020 and the grand prize winner will be announced on March 13, 2020!

They grow up so fast. Now's your chance to shape their future. Responding to the U.S. Census helps your community get its fair share of funding. It’s easier than ever to respond to the census. You can respond in 13 different languages, and you can complete it online, by phone or by mail. On Census Day — April 1, 2020 — start shaping your future and the futures of all our children by counting everyone in your home.

Find out more at census.gov/schools.

Be counted in the 2020 Census! More information is available at https://henrico.us/census/.

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating the MathCounts team from Moody Middle School on a thrilling win at the Middle School Chapter MathCounts competition that took place Feb. 15! The team of 10 swept the competition and six will go on to compete at the state competition March 14 — Pi Day!

Team members include: Pooshan Chaudhuri, Rachel Dai, Qingyuan (Eric) Hu, Devesh Kumar, Shorya Malani, Sattwik Nath, Timothy Porter, Yash Saxena, Natalie Xie, and Tony Zhang. Chaudhuri, Dai, Hu, Saxena, Xie and Zhang will compete at the state competition in March.

MathCounts is a national competition with thousands across the United States participating. Moody Middle has competed every year with 10 members chosen out of 70 students to compete. Last year their team of four placed fifth. Congrats again and good luck at States next month!

post_text:
FRIDAY UPDATE: Our transportation team has been out on the roads this morning, and based on what they’re seeing, it appears the loneliest man in town won’t have a reason to call today...

Henrico County Public Schools will open ON TIME today, Friday, February 21, 2020. Our buses will be driven cautiously this morning, and we ask that everyone consider joining us in doing the same.

Las Escuelas Públicas del Condado de Henrico abrirán a tiempo el día de hoy.

Due to the early hour, we won’t ‘ring’ or ‘ding’ your phone with a robocall or text, but information can still be found on our social media. If you aren’t getting our messages, please check with your school to see if your contact information and preferences are up to date.

And for general information about this and other types of announcements, visit this page: https://henricoschools.us/communications/

Have a great Friday!

post_text:
THURSDAY UPDATE 2:51 pm: Due to our shared concerns about the incoming snowy weather, all Henrico County Public Schools will close at 6:00 tonight, Thursday, February 20, 2020.

Activities scheduled to begin at or after 6:00 p.m. will be postponed or cancelled.

Activities and events that would have ended after 6:00 p.m. will end by 6:00 p.m.

Individual teams, groups and/or organizations may make additional schedule adjustments in light of this announcement.

No decision yet about any impact to school or activities on Friday.

Need an idea for family movie night? We hear this one has good reviews, but we’ll be back later to officially decide if it's based on a true story ...or... just science fiction… 😉😉😉

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating Chris Mitchell, a senior from Tucker High School, on winning the Harry F. Byrd, Jr. Leadership Award!

The Harry F. Byrd, Jr. Leadership Award was established by Senator Byrd in 1994. This program rewards high school students who demonstrate academic accomplishment and who also embody excellence of character, leadership, and good citizenship.

Over 300 students across Virginia applied. Thirty-three students were interviewed and 11 were selected as winners – one per congressional district. Chris was the winner for the 7th district!

Congratulations Chris!

post_text:
HCPS offers Early Learning Preschool at our 26 different locations for students who will turn 4 by September 30, 2020.

When you're ready to apply, go to henricoschools.us/preschool and click on the blue box that says ‘Apply Now!’ to complete the online application. Then come to one of our Recruitment Events in February or March to complete the process (please make sure you have all of the required documentation). There are several recruitments planned for your convenience and you only need to attend one.

If you have questions at any time during the process, please email us at preschool@henrico.k12.va.us.

Or, just use this link to get started: https://henricoschools.us/preschool/

Letters letting you know of your students’ enrollment status will be sent out in July.

post_text:
"I serve as an active participant in a larger society" are attributes of the Henrico Learner Profile Philip Kamper took to heart. When Kamper, a senior at Hermitage High School’s Center for the Humanities, learned about the horrors of human trafficking he knew he had to do something.

For Kamper's senior project he planned and coordinated a community information session that took place on Jan. 15 to address the growing issue of human trafficking in our society. Kamper planned the event from start to finish from advertising, and communicating with speakers to securing the venue. As a result of his efforts, more than 100 members from the community came out!

Kamper's project was also featured in the Catholic Virginian, https://www.catholicvirginian.org/?p=11166.

Thank you Philip for showing us what it means to be a Global Citizen!

post_text:
Feb. 17 (Monday) is the deadline to request a variance:

While school-age children who reside with their parents or guardian are required to attend the school that serves the area in which they live, certain circumstances stated in School Board regulation R6-03-011 allow a parent or guardian to apply for a variance for their child to attend another Henrico County school.

Henrico County Public Schools has established deadlines to request a variance to another school beginning with the 2020-21 school year. The deadline to request a variance for high schools is Feb. 17, 2020. The variance information regarding variances can be found at https://henricoschools.us/school-assignmentvariance/. You can also contact your child’s school for questions related to variance requests.

Applying for a variance does not guarantee one will be granted.

post_text:
Check out these cool photos of construction at Elizabeth Holladay Elementary School! The new wing will double the school's size.

See updates and drone video at our construction page: https://henricoschools.us/building-for-the-future/. You can also check out progress on the replacement schools for Highland Springs H.S. and J.R. Tucker H.S. All three projects will open and welcome students and staff members in fall 2021.

The Holladay addition is being paid for through the 2016 bond referendum, which Henrico voters approved by a vote of 84%. The high schools are also being financed with bond-referendum funding, along with funds from the 2013 voter-approved meals tax. Thank you for supporting public education in our community!

What was so popular last year that required two days this year? Why, the Grandparents Day Breakfast at Ratcliffe Elementary of course! Grandparents were treated to breakfast with their grandchildren and also made Valentine's Day cards. The event was planned by Leslie McGuinn, Ratcliffe's family advocate, with support from the community and the Title 1 reading coaches.

Shout-out to Rev. Dr. Price L. Davis of Mosby Memorial Baptist Church for his support in serving up all of the pancakes!

Looks like a great time had by all! Next time save us a pancake!

Please join us in congratulating Perisa Ashar, a former Henrico student at Colonial Trial Elementary School and the Moody Middle School IB program, for winning the National Award from the National Center of Women in Technology, and the Distinguished Finalist Award for Virginia in the 2020 Prudential Spirit of Community Awards!

Perisa, a current student at Maggie L. Walker Governor’s School, was one of the 40 national winners out of 4,700 for the National Award for Women in Computing Aspirations in Technology Award. Way to go Perisa!

post_text:
You've probably heard the name Virginia Randolph, but do you know her legacy? Randolph was born during the Reconstruction era and opened the one-room Mountain Road School for black children in 1892. Randolph was a major figure in advancing education in our community and in Virginia for decades. Since school transportation was not provided, she often let children stay in her home so they could attend. To learn more about Virginia Randolph check out https://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Randolph_Virginia_Estelle_1870-1958#start_entry. Or make a trip to the museum honoring Randolph's work: https://henrico.us/rec/places/virginia-randolph-museum/.

Check out what else is happening in the Richmond area for Black History Month at https://rvahub.com/2020/01/30/vmfa-announces-full-roster-of-events-celebrating-black-history-month/.

post_text:
Congratulations to the students and teachers of Henrico High School Mock Trial who placed first, second and third at the Regional Competition! They also won the top witness and top attorney awards!

Now you may be asking yourself, "What is a mock trial?" Mock Trial is a competition where students act out a civil or criminal trial by arguing for either the prosecution or defense against another team. The case is tried in front of judges, who rate their performance.

Congrats again and good luck at the state competition in March!

post_text:
The legacy of community leader Art Washburn will continue on. The Art Washburn Community Classic took place last Saturday (Feb. 1st) and teams from Benedictine, Deep Run, J.R. Tucker, and the Steward School played two basketball games in his honor. Art was a fixture in the community and would often be found at numerous Deep Run sporting events where his two boys attended school.

Proceeds from the event went to numerous organizations including the Deep Run Athletic Booster Memorial Senior Scholarship, FeedMore, March of Dimes Richmond, among others.

To watch the full video with captions, please click here: https://youtu.be/s3FwysXliXE

post_text:
This message is only for families of John Rolfe Middle School and Varina High School:

Due to a weather-related transformer fire that has resulted in the loss of electricity, JRMS and VHS will dismiss early today.

John Rolfe Middle School will dismiss students at 11:30 a.m.

Varina High School will dismiss students at 12:30 p.m.

Neighboring elementary schools will not be dismissed early, as conditions at these schools are conducive to continuing the instructional day. While other HCPS schools are dealing with power outages, there are no additional early dismissals planned at this time.

In order to maximize safety, bus drivers will proceed with caution and routes may take longer than usual. Students will be dismissed in accordance with the preferences listed on the emergency closure form completed at the beginning of the year. If you indicated parent pickup in the event of an emergency, please make arrangements accordingly.

School phone lines are also being affected by the outage.

Andy Jenks
Chief of Communications and Community Engagement
Henrico County Public Schools

post_text:
At 7:30 p.m. (Tuesday): Check out the Varina HS student-run livestream of the Atlee/Varina boys' varsity basketball game!

Staff members in Henrico Schools’ Department of Communications and Public Relations will direct the production, handle the main camera and play-by-play duties, and offer advice, but the students will do the bulk of the work. Students will rotate positions throughout the games, giving more students a chance to participate.

The live student production can be viewed by going to https://henricoschools.us/live-stream-event/ just before game time.

post_text:
Additional ‘We The People’ shout-out! Last week, we recognized Douglas S. Freeman High School’s ‘Team Rehnquist’ for being WTP state champions and Glen Allen High School’s ‘Team Bingham’ for being WTP regional champions. We also want to congratulate GAHS’s ‘Team Grant’ for finishing 3rd at states. Way to go!

Team members are:

Logan Anderson, Jaden Battle, Taylor Biltz, Emma Bonovitch, Maggie Byrne, Wade Carter, Abigail Charleston, Rebekah Cohodas, Isabelle Fogleman, Parker Holland, Katelyn Kasko, Kaitlin Layton, Lauren Meyer, Nathan Morris, Victoria Osenga, Colin Richter, Jasmine Rios, Sarah Rockecharlie, Matthew Rooney, Gwendolyn Sargent, Alexa Spain, Katie Taguchi, Hayden Taylor, Anna van Marcke de Lummen, Sophia Ventura, Lauren Waggoner

Their teachers are Ryan Conway and Schuyler VanValkenburg.

The competition simulates a congressional hearing, with students testifying on questions of American history, government, politics, and Constitutional law.

For photos and names of Team Rehnquist and Team Bingham, scroll down to last week’s posts.

71 degrees on February 3? HCPS winter weather graphics are on clearance! Everything must go!

Like this item: An image of our snow-day announcer guy, holding a shovel. He doesn’t need that shovel! He needs a lawnmower and some spring annuals!

(But seriously folks, shout-out to Varina High School’s Jonathan Gosney who made us a bunch of cool *pun intended* weather graphics, and at this point we’re going to find a way to use them whether we get any snow this year or not!)

post_text:
Henrico High School student performers wowed attendees at Thursday's monthly meeting of the Henrico School Board. The students are enrolled in the Music Theater II class at the Henrico Center for the Arts, and were under the direction of Billy Dye.

Students from Longan Elementary School led the Pledge.

January's Helping Hand Volunteer Award winners — Julia and Todd Levy of Varina Elementary School — were also honored.

The School Board recognized Virginia High School League 5A state champions from Deep Run High School:
- Golf state champions.
- Girls’ cross country state champions.
- Boys’ volleyball state champions.
- Competitive cheer state champions.

Also honored were teachers achieving and renewing their certification from the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards in 2019.

If you see your School Board member in February, be sure to say "Thanks" as part of Virginia School Board Appreciation Month! Gov. Northam proclaimed February 2020 as School Board Appreciation Month to help build awareness of the crucial role school board members plays in our communities and schools.

Pictured are: Micky Ogburn, vice-chair and Three Chopt District representative; Marcie Shea, Tuckahoe District representative; Roscoe Cooper III, chair and Fairfield District representative; Alicia Atkins, Varina District representative; and Kristi Kinsella, Brookland District.

Want to know more about the Henrico School Board, attend meetings or find out who your representative is? Go to https://henricoschools.us/school-board/.

Schools are "Celebrating Kindness" during the month of January, and representatives from the third-and-fourth-grade student council (SCA) at Springfield Park Elementary School had the sweetest way of recognizing some very special people! On Tuesday morning police officers and firefighters were served a hot breakfast. They were also presented with handwritten cards and thank-you notes from the students to show appreciation for the work they do! This is the second year that the "kindness breakfast" has taken place.

How are YOU practicing kindness this month? Shout it out in the comments!

post_text:
Please join us in congratulating Tyler Dunaway, a spanish teacher at Moody Middle School, who has been selected as a recipient of VASCD's 2020 Impact Award! The Impact Award is given each year to professionals who consistently challenge themselves and others to learn, grow and achieve at the highest possible performance levels.

The Virginia Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development is comprised of more than 1,200 teachers, administrators and higher education faculty. The group supports excellence in teaching, learning and leadership through innovative, proactive policies and programs designed to foster lifelong learning.

Thank you Tyler for everything that you do! We are honored to have you as a teacher!

Join us in congratulating Kevin Robertson on being honored at the 34th Annual Martin Luther King, Jr. Commemoration Celebration (Monday) for his Outstanding Community Service in Henrico County!

Kevin, an Henrico High School graduate, has been the family advocate for the past four years at Donahoe Elementary and is praised for his devotion to the students and community, the willingness to get the job done and being an all-around asset to the staff and students!

Congratulations Kevin and keep up the great work that you are doing for Henrico County!

post_text:
How are you saying THANKS this week?

Gov. Northam has proclaimed Jan. 19-25 “Virginia School Principals Appreciation Week.” Principals do it all – from encouraging students, to hiring the right teachers, to managing large buildings. The week is a chance to note “the hard work of Virginia school principals and to recognize the importance of principals in ensuring that every child has access to a quality education,” said the governor’s proclamation. From a card to a shoutout, why not find a way to say thanks to your principal?

Read the proclamation at https://www.governor.virginia.gov/newsroom/proclamations/proclamation/-virginia-school-principals-appreciation-week.html.

post_text:
The drug task force at Varina High School is planning several events to educate adults on the perils of youth substance abuse. The first event, Hidden in Plain Sight, will be tonight (Wednesday) at 6 p.m. at Varina High School.

Hidden in Plain Sight is an educational experience that walks parents through a typical teenage bedroom. The inside of the bedroom is set up with drug paraphernalia “Hidden in Plain Sight.” This is an interactive display/program that offers adults insights into current trends in youth substance abuse, drug paraphernalia, concealment of illicit drugs and alcohol. Parents only please!

post_text:
Know a student artist? They could have their artwork considered for thank-you cards to teachers across Virginia. They could also win $2,000 for their school's art department, and a $150 gift card.

The Virginia Lottery's "Thank a Teacher Art Contest" is seeking three student artists whose work will be featured on teacher thank-you notes distributed across the commonwealth. The contest is open to K-12 students enrolled in a Virginia public school.

Hurry! Submissions are accepted through Jan. 31.

Each year, the Virginia Lottery encourages students, parents and the public to send thank-you notes to public school teachers during Teacher Appreciation Week. Will the next batch feature your work?

One winner will be selected from each level: elementary school, middle school and high school. The three winners will not only get to see their artwork featured on the 2020 thank-you notes, but they’ll also receive a $150 gift card and win $2,000 for their school's art department.

Help us spread the word. For more information about the contest, visit thankateacherva.com.

post_text:
Help Henrico County be accurately represented in the 2020 U.S. Census! Pay starts at $21 an hour, with flexible hours and paid training. Go to https://2020census.gov/en/jobs.html and find out more about joining Henrico's Census team.

Why is the Census count important for Henrico? The Census, conducted every 10 years since 1790, determines the amount of federal funding distributed to states for programs that affect our community. It also one of the main tools used to plan for future communities and services. It determine's Virginia's number of representatives to the U.S. House.

For schools, the U.S. Census guides federal spending programs that affect schools and students, including Title I grants to local educational agencies, the national school lunch and breakfast programs, special education grants, career and technical education grants, the Title IV-E foster care program, Section 8 housing assistance, Head Start programs and more.

Undercounting in a census can lead a state to have lower levels of funding and underrepresentation in Congress.

post_text:
Calling student artists (or their families): Your artwork could be featured on thank-you cards to teachers throughout Virginia. Students could also win $2,000 for their school's art department, and a $150 gift card.

The Virginia Lottery's "Thank a Teacher Art Contest" is seeking three student artists whose work will be featured on teacher thank-you notes distributed across the commonwealth. The contest is open to K-12 students enrolled in a Virginia public school. Hurry! Submissions are accepted through Jan. 31.

Each year, the Virginia Lottery encourages students, parents and the public to send thank-you notes to public school teachers during Teacher Appreciation Week. Will the next batch feature your work?

One winner will be selected from each level: elementary school, middle school and high school. The three winners will not only get to see their artwork featured on the 2020 thank-you notes, but they’ll also receive a $150 gift card and win $2,000 for their school's art department. Help us spread the word. For more information about the contest, visit thankateacherva.com.

Tune in tonight (Tuesday) starting at 7 p.m. when champions from each of Henrico County Public Schools’ 45 elementary schools and 12 middle schools will square off in the 2020 HCPS Divisionwide Spelling Bee!

The winner of the HCPS bee will advance to the Richmond Times-Dispatch regional spelling competition in March for a chance to represent a large swath of Virginia in the Scripps National Spelling Bee. The Scripps contest features more than 280 regional champions from around the
nation, and is televised by ESPN.

The annual matchup of orthographic titans will be streamed live by HCPS-TV. You can watch on your computer or mobile devices by going to the division’s website at https://henricoschools.us/live-stream-event/.

post_text:
A message to the Moody Middle School community from Principal Denise Doss...

Dear Raider families,

First of all, let me thank you for your patience and understanding today. No parent, teacher or principal ever wants to go through an emergency situation like the one we had today, but I’m so proud to say our staff and students responded well and put into action what we have practiced.

Although the police investigation remains ongoing, we can say confidently, once again, that there was never an ‘active shooter’ on the premises. Still, we know our students may have concerns about school tomorrow [Tuesday], so we have arranged for an additional police presence as well as additional school counselors who will be on site tomorrow [Tuesday] to provide our school community with the necessary support.

Thank you for helping us keep safety as a number one priority, and we look forward to seeing everyone again on Tuesday.

Denise Doss

post_text:
Meet your School Board: Marcie Shea (Tuckahoe District)!

Marcie F. Shea was elected in November 2019 to represent the Tuckahoe District on the Henrico School Board. Mrs. Shea is both a parent and former teacher in the Tuckahoe District. She taught college prep, honors and Advanced Placement physics at Douglas Freeman High School.

Mrs. Shea earned a physics degree from Samford University as well as a Master of Education in curriculum and instruction from Virginia Tech.

As a classroom teacher, she was recognized by Henrico County for cultivating critical thinking with her students and was a fellow in the national Discovery Education STEM program.

After stepping away from the full-time high school classroom, Mrs. Shea has continued to invest in Henrico schools through instructional coaching, working one-on-one with high school students, as well as serving on the PTA and various Henrico Schools committees.

She is married to husband Mason Shea. They have two children, Bradley and Opal.

Welcome!

And, to see all our Board members, visit us here: https://henricoschools.us/school-board/

post_text:
A New Year's tradition was born this week – one that celebrates the art of HCPS students. Henrico Schools is sending out a New Year's card to school and other officials around Virginia. The card will feature artwork from Ashley Powers, a junior at Glen Allen High School and a digital media student. Her delightful creation featured flowers and fronds shaped like the profile of Pocahontas that is featured in Henrico Schools' logo.

Future cards will feature art from other schools.

Finalists were Ashley's classmates Tomas Carrillo, Peyton Fristoe, Katie Murphy and Blake Olsen.

The class is taught by Erin Mable.

post_text: Panthers in Peru! Check out this group of Hermitage High School students on a Winter Break trip that included visits to Machu Picchu and Lima! Teachers Dana Franson and Chip Dell made sure to bring the #hcpsflag along for the journey. “We open it up to the whole school, so all students are welcome,” Dana told us. “We’ve taught about Peru and the Incan empire, so seeing it was a natural thought for us … Experiencing the topics we’ve taught with some of our own students is such a rewarding experience!”

post_text:
Meet your School Board: Kristi Kinsella (Brookland District)!

(A new year brings a new version of the Henrico School Board. In the next few days, we'll be introducing all five School Board members to you, in alphabetical order of their magisterial district.)

Kristi Briggs Kinsella was elected Brookland District School Board representative in November. She is a longtime resident of the Brookland District and a graduate of Hermitage High School. She earned her degree in finance from Virginia Commonwealth University.

Mrs. Kinsella has decades of business and analytical experience. She co-founded the advocacy group Equitable Advocates and co-chaired the Henrico Lay Advisory Committee. In addition, she has volunteered at her children’s schools, their PTAs and served on various HCPS committees.

Welcome!

And, to see all our Board members, visit us here: https://henricoschools.us/school-board/

post_text:
Meet your new School Board!

A new year brings a new version of the Henrico School Board. In the next few days, we'll be introducing all five School Board members to you, in alphabetical order of their magisterial district. The members, from left to right in the photo, are:

• Micky Ogburn (Three Chopt District).*
• Marcie Shea (Tuckahoe District).
• Roscoe Cooper III (Fairfield District).*
• Alicia Atkins (Varina District).
• Kristi Kinsella (Brookland District).

*Returning School Board member

The Board says goodbye and a big thanks to John Montgomery (12 years as Varina District representative), Beverly Cocke (eight years as Brookland District representative) and Bill Pike (14 months as Tuckahoe District representative). The three members stepped down from the School Board after thoughtful and dedicated service to Henrico families.

post_text:
Every year employees at HCPS Central Office are honored to join with the Henrico Christmas Mother to help those in need in our community. Christmas Mother Andrea Collins stopped by the administration headquarters and accepted a check from Amy Cashwell, HCPS superintendent. Funds were raised by Central Office staff members through donations and an annual online auction of donated items. Holiday entertainment was provided by talented students from Arthur Ashe Elementary School.

A big thank you to everyone in our schools who donated tons (literally) of canned goods and other food to the Christmas Mother campaign; to the members of the facilities department who transported all that food to the Christmas Mother warehouse; to the Equity Ambassadors who volunteered at the warehouse; and to all the school and community volunteers who helped make it all happen!

post_text:
His first grade daughter had no idea what was about to happen. Watch, as Captain Aaron Ingersoll of the U.S. Army's Second Combat Aviation Brigade, returned home from South Korea in a surprise visit to Kaechele Elementary School.

Captain Ingersoll had been stationed at Camp Humphreys in South Korea for more than four months. As for the surprise homecoming, he told us "The feeling was indescribable. To see her face and have her friends be part of it and her school. Definitely a great event."

Wishing all of our community a safe, wonderful and joyous Winter Break with family and friends!

post_text:
New Bridge Learning Center hosted a bittersweet afternoon reception Wednesday to celebrate the terms of three retiring School Board members.

HCPS staff members, county and state officials, former colleagues, friends and family members said "thank you" to John Montgomery (12 years as Varina District representative), Beverly Cocke (eight years as Brookland District representative) and Bill Pike (14 months as Tuckahoe District representative). The three members stepped down from the School Board after thoughtful and dedicated service to Henrico families. The occasion featured a wonderful catered spread (including a cake and holiday treats) prepared by students in the Highland Springs High School culinary arts program.

Board members were presented with framed caricatures drawn by student Eian Hertzler at the Center for the Arts at Henrico HS. They also received framed prints of a piece by Glen Allen HS digital media student Ashley Powers. Her card will appear on HCPS official New Years card which will go out to school and other officials around Virginia.

post_text:
U.S. Rep. Donald McEachin and members of his staff were at Highland Springs HS this week to present the school's library with more than 200 books as part of an outreach program by The Library of Congress.

Among those joining McEachin for the presentation were HCPS library services staff members, John Montgomery (Varina District representative on the School Board), Alicia Atkins (the Varina District's representative-elect) and Ken White, the school's principal.

The fiction and nonfiction books from will help keep HSHS's collection current, with relevant high-interest resources that support content that students are learning.

Congressman Donald McEachin

post_text:
A cold, rainy afternoon didn't temper excitement Friday for the official groundbreaking of an addition that will double the size of Elizabeth Holladay Elementary School. The addition will open for the 2021-22 school year.

Students, staff members, construction team members and Henrico County dignitaries gathered to hear speeches, celebrate the school's history and enjoy music from members of the Hermitage HS Marching Panthers.

Holladay Elementary School uses the Leader in Me program, based on Stephen Covey's "Seven Habits of Highly Effective People," and was the first public school in Virginia to be honored as a Lighthouse School in that program. The school will be the first in central Virginia to have a dual-immersion program, where students will learn in both English and Spanish.

The addition at Holladay was approved by Henrico voters with an 84% yes vote as part of the 2016 bond referendum.

Students, staff members, construction team members and Henrico County dignitaries gathered to hear speeches, celebrate the school's history and enjoy music from members of the Hermitage HS Marching Panthers.

Holladay Elementary School uses the Leader in Me program, based on Stephen Covey's "Seven Habits of Highly Effective People," and was the first public school in Virginia to be honored as a Lighthouse School in that program. The school will be the first in central Virginia to have a dual-immersion program, where students will learn in both English and Spanish.

The addition at Holladay was approved by Henrico voters with an 84% yes vote as part of the 2016 bond referendum.
