Thanks to everyone in our community who has supported the Henrico Christmas Mother campaign – including all our HCPS families who have donated canned goods and other food! The campaign makes the holiday season brighter for our neighbors in need. So many people have helped out – including, this week, Henrico County Public Schools' Equity Ambassadors, which includes student representatives from all nine HCPS high schools. The students pitched in at the Henrico Christmas Mother warehouse in eastern Henrico County.

There's still time to help! Go to http://henricochristmasmother.org to find out how.

(A special shoutout to this year's Christmas Mother, Andrea Collins! 👏👏👏)

Full disclosure: Syracuse lost both games but let’s not get into that right now…”

post_text:
HCPS alumni flying high in STEAM careers!

It's Thanksgiving, so maybe you're concerned with adjusting your belt after a big meal. For J.R. Tucker High School alumna Alice Bowman, it's more about the Kuiper Belt. Bowman, who spoke at the JRTHS convocation in 2015, heads up the New Horizons Mission Operations at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Lab in Maryland – the first woman to earn that role. She leads about 40 scientists in supervising one of NASA's most distant spacecraft.

You can hear her speak Wednesday at noon about NASA's mission to Pluto and the Kuiper Belt, as part of "Lunch Break Science" at the Science Museum of Virginia.

post_text:
Manage your HCPS communications with the SchoolMessenger app
The new SchoolMessenger app allows you to set preferences and keep track of communications from HCPS, from individual schools and from teachers who use SchoolMessenger. Just search for “SchoolMessenger” where you download apps or visit go.schoolmessenger.com for information on how to sign up. (Please note that the app will only work with the email address you have on file with your school.) Once you've created an account, you can:

- Review the past 30 days’ worth of messages from HCPS or your student’s school.
- View your contact information and set preferences for how you’d like to receive notifications.
- Get classroom communications if your child’s teacher uses SchoolMessenger.

post_text:
THANKS to everyone who came out to our two recent redistricting presentations and gallery walks! Your contribution to this process is invaluable! The two sessions, held at L. Douglas Wilder MS and Mills Godwin HS, were well attended. Families and staff members got to see draft option maps, hear from Matt Cropper (Cropper GIS redistricting consultant), and talk with members of the 67-person redistricting committee about their ideas and concerns.

Didn't make it to the sessions? Don't worry! You can still share your thoughts with the committee. An important survey about the two draft maps is available at our website at https://henricoschools.us/redistricting/, and there are also interactive maps to explore.

You can also see video of Matt Cropper's redistricting presentation by clicking on "Calendar and Documents."

post_text: Holman Middle School English teacher Joan Hodges made a special request to mark two milestones in her life. This is her 25th year of teaching and she’s also turning 50 in November. Her goal was to have books donated to her so she could give one to every student in her class. She put out a post on social media and received more than 200 books! Joan's students will be turning the pages on some great books all year long.

Just search for “SchoolMessenger” where you download apps or visit go.schoolmessenger.com for information on how to sign up. (Please note that the app will only work with the email address you have on file with your school.) Once you've created an account, you can:

- Review the past 30 days’ worth of messages from HCPS or your student’s school.
- View your contact information and set preferences for how you’d like to receive notifications.
- Get classroom communications if your child’s teacher uses SchoolMessenger.

post_text: On a crisp Saturday, Tuckahoe Middle School celebrated its 60th anniversary with games, food trucks and activities – and showed off its new sparkle! In 2016, Henrico voters approved a major bond issue for school renovation and construction, with 84% approval. It included $28.2 million to renovate Tuckahoe Middle School, built in 1958. Congratulations Patriots, and thank you to Henrico's citizens for your passion for education!

In 2016, Henrico voters approved a major bond issue for school renovation and construction, with 84% approval. It included $28.2 million to renovate Tuckahoe Middle School, built in 1958. Congratulations Patriots, and thank you to Henrico's citizens for your passion for education!

post_text:
Be involved! Redistricting Draft Options A and B are now available. Visit https://henricoschools.us/redistricting/ to have a look, take a survey, and plan to attend one of our public information sessions/gallery walks on Nov. 7 or 13.

We need your thoughts on these two options. Nothing is final now – but that’s the point! The committee will be making changes based on what they hear from the public.

Why did the committee choose these two draft options? The members strongly considered six draft options, and chose to present these two because they thought they best satisfied the aims of redistricting: to efficiently use available space and plan for growth; to account for the addition to Holladay Elementary School and the increased capacity of the new J.R. Tucker and Highland Springs high schools, opening in 2021; and to reduce concentrations of poverty, while balancing that goal with a neighborhood-school concept.

9:43 p.m. update*: Please join us in congratulating incumbents Roscoe Cooper (Fairfield), Micky Ogburn (Three Chopt), and NEW Henrico County School Board members-elect Kristi Kinsella (Brookland), Marcie Shea (Tuckahoe) and Alicia Atkins (Varina). We look forward to your leadership!

We also share our sincere gratitude for outgoing members John Montgomery (Varina, 3 terms), Beverly Cocke (Brookland, 2 terms), and Bill Pike (Tuckahoe) for their years of dedicated public service! (But they still have two more months to go, so it’s not goodbye just yet!)

post_text:
Wednesday evening: come to "Silent No More," and be part of a supportive solution to the opioid crisis. The event at Varina HS will give a voice to families who've suffered a loss due to opioid overdoses, and shine light on an increasing societal problem. Guest speakers Jenny Derr and Jennifer Tolson will share stories about their children, lost to opioid overdoses.

Come show support for families navigating this crisis, and help amplify this powerful message as we continue to raise awareness and take a stand against this epidemic. Be part of a supportive environment and talk with community organizations.

The event was organized by the Varina HS Drug Task Force, a school group that raises awareness about drug use and prevention.

• Nov. 6 from 6:30-8 p.m., Varina High School, 7053 Messer Road, Henrico, Va.

It was an inspirational moment recently when Patty Griffin, our former education specialist for gifted education, was recognized posthumously as the Virginia Association for the Gifted’s Leader of the Year. Patty passed away in April of this year.

Chandra Floyd, Henrico gifted specialist, along with Patty’s family, accepted the award at the association’s conference in October.

The Henrico Education Foundation recently established a fund in Patty’s memory to benefit gifted programs. To contribute, visit https://henricogives.org/ and click on “Donate”.

Have you ever seen a more amazing combination of cuteness and kindness?! Earlier this week, these babies were dressed in Halloween costumes designed and sewed by students in the Glen Allen High School 'Intro to Fashion Careers' course. The babies are being loved and cared for in the NICU at Bon Secours Richmond Health System St. Mary's Hospital. All of the costumes are smaller than a sheet of paper...about 10 x 7 inches.

Thanks to GAHS's Shana Katz for the photos!

The first-ever Henrico Career & Technical Education - CTE Life-Ready Expo was a huge success! Crowds of families turned out at the Advanced Career Education Center at Hermitage to talk with employers, find out about career pathways, learn about multiple ways to “learn and earn” through employer programs, tour the ACE Center and talk with current seniors about their coursework and where they’re headed.

Don't forget that HCPS will also host a separate event Tuesday evening: the division’s annual College and Career Night (Oct. 29 from 6-8 p.m. at Mills Godwin High School, 2101 Pump Road). That event will feature representatives of more than 100 colleges and universities, as well as more than 50 employers. To find out more about the event, go to https://henricoschools.us/henrico-county-college-and-career-night-its-like-a-buffet-for-your-future/

post_text: Our hearts (and stomachs!) are full...
shared_text:
Henrico County Police
October 24, 2019 at 10:19 AM ·

Ms. Ferris, the teacher of the culinary arts program at Varina High school, was approached by her students over concerns they have regarding some of the police interactions they’ve seen in the news and she decided she wanted to do something to help educate the students. Ms. Ferris, with the help of the students, created a homemade lunch and asked officers to sit down and eat with them to discuss current issues and to break barriers by showing the students that Henrico Officers are real people just like them. Henrico County Public Schools

post_text:
A word of appreciation for our entire Transportation team, from Superintendent Amy Cashwell...

October includes both “National School Bus Safety Week” and today, which is “School Bus Transportation Employees Appreciation Day” in Virginia.

I want to take a moment to express my deep appreciation for what you do every day as a member of the Transportation team.

You complete demanding daily missions, despite a shortage of drivers.

You come to work every day, often completing extra routes and other work with a sense of urgency.

You make sure our children get to school safely and in good spirits, so they can learn.

And you do it with care, love and dedication.

I offer my sincere gratitude for the critical role you play in educating Henrico’s children.

Please join me in thanking our entire Transportation team!

Crowds gathered Monday evening at Hermitage High School’s Chester E. Fritz Stadium for some crisp October weather – and the amazing sounds of all nine HCPS high school bands! Here are some photos of the Varina, Hermitage and Highland Springs bands.

This morning we posted photos of the first three bands to perform – Henrico, J.R. Tucker and Deep Run. This evening we'll post photos of the final three participants: Glen Allen, Douglas Freeman and Mills Godwin.

The night ended with a powerful moment: all nine high school bands took the field to play along with band members from all HCPS middle schools!

post_text:
Students from 23 Henrico County elementary schools took to the baseball field recently to learn how to field, hit and run the bases. The students took part in Challenger Day, an annual event that introduces students with significant disabilities to the fundamentals of baseball. The students also enjoyed games, crafts, therapy dogs, roaming mascots and a picnic lunch. More than 370 students attended, and volunteers were on hand to work with the students in grades K-5 and their teachers.

Challenger Day is an offshoot of the Challenger Division of Little League Baseball, a league for children with cognitive and physical disabilities. The program helps provide participants with many of the benefits of athletic competition: exercise, socialization, teamwork, sportsmanship and self-esteem.

The event is a collaboration of the Henrico Education Foundation, Capital One, the I Have a Dream Found Foundation - Richmond, Henrico County Recreation & Parks , Henrico County Public Schools, Tuckahoe Sports, Inc. and Tuckahoe Little League.

What says fall more than marching bands, stadium crowds and crisp October weather? Get your dose of autumn and see all nine of Henrico County’s high school marching bands in action at the HCPS Band Showcase Oct. 21 at Hermitage High School’s Chester E. Fritz Stadium.

The event is free, but donations are being accepted to benefit the Henrico Christmas Mother. In addition to cash donations, the holiday campaign is seeking canned food; jars of peanut butter; cereal and crackers; and new hats, gloves and socks.

Refreshments will be available for purchase at the event.

Henrico County Public Schools Band Showcase

Who:
The public and media are invited to attend.
When:
Oct. 21 from 6:30-8:30 p.m.
Where:
Hermitage High School
8301 Hungary Spring Road
Henrico, Va. 23228

post_text:
Tuesday: Come to a countywide PTA meeting!

Are you a PTA member at your student’s school? Come to the Henrico County Council of PTAs meeting Oct. 15 at L. Douglas Wilder Middle School. The meeting will discuss advocating for education and will offer information to PTA groups on how the actions of our lawmakers affect health, safety and education in our schools, and how you can be involved in that process. The meeting will also include magisterial-district breakout sessions where attendees can talk with their School Board representative. Amy Cashwell, HCPS superintendent, will present a short update on school division initiatives and recent accomplishments.

The Henrico County Council of PTAs includes representatives of the individual school PTA organizations in Henrico County.

Henrico County Council of PTAs meeting
When: Oct. 15 at 6:30 p.m.
Where: L. Douglas Wilder Middle School, 6900 Wilkinson Road, Henrico, Va. 23227

Express your views about public education in Henrico County! Did you know that each monthly meeting of the Henrico School Board includes a time dedicated to public comments?

The next meeting is Oct. 24. Monthly Board meetings begin at 6:30 p.m. and take place at New Bridge Learning Center, 5915 Nine Mile Road, in eastern Henrico County. For dates of upcoming monthly meetings and work sessions, go to https://henricoschools.us/school-board/.

While signing up beforehand isn't required, doing so reserves a place during the public comment period. To sign up, email or call the clerk of the School Board. For contact info, go to https://henricoschools.us/school-board/.

post_text:
Want to make a big difference for a student in grades 3-5 during the 2019-20 school year? All it takes is 30-45 minutes per week from October to May. Come to a two-hour training session Oct. 23 and get started with Henrico Schools’ award-winning mentoring program, Henrico HEROES.

- Oct. 23 from 1:30-3:30 p.m. at 1440 N. Laburnum Ave., Henrico, Va. (Eastern Henrico Recreation Center Randolph room).

The process of becoming a Henrico HEROES mentor is easy. Mentors complete an application, undergo a background check, and attend a two-hour training session. Mentors meet with their student once a week for 30-45 minutes from October to May and participate in a programwide kickoff and end-of-year celebration.

Studies show that mentoring pays big dividends for students. It improves students’ attendance and academic motivation, and students with a mentor are more likely to enroll in college, to volunteer and to be involved in sports and other extracurricular activities.

post_text:
The gas leak has been repaired and Ridge Elementary School will open ON TIME on Tuesday, Oct. 8.

And now, a word of thanks. Let’s give it up for the Ridge Elementary School students who were amazing while they were outside! Thank you, as well, to their families for paying close attention to the urgent messages that were sent about today’s early dismissal. We’d also like to commend the Ridge faculty and staff, and our bus drivers for their quick thinking, fast responses and heartfelt attention to student needs. Tuckahoe Middle School teachers and staff members were tremendously helpful, too, providing resources and extra help to make this unexpected event run as smoothly as possible. We are so proud of the teamwork!

If you did not receive the emails, texts, or phone calls on a number/email that you prefer, please let the Ridge Elementary School office know so that they may make the adjustment. We want to ensure that you are receiving communication from us in a manner that is most helpful in an emergency.

Again, Ridge Elementary School will open ON TIME on Tuesday, Oct. 8!

post_text:
Shoutout to Moody Middle School sixth-grader Caleb Scott, who won the 2019 National Inventors Challenge for his age group with his invention, the EZ Door Opener! The invention began as his Nuckols Farm Elementary School science fair project, before taking the national Alexander Graham Bell Prize for grades 3–5.

Caleb's EZ Door Opener makes it easier to open doors, and is designed for (but not limited to) pets, babies and elderly people.

To find out more about the challenge, go to https://imagination.live/inventors-challenge-2019-winners-18c51cef5756.

post_text:
Enjoy these pics from Sandston Elementary School, which recently celebrated its "Exemplar Performance School Award" from the Virginia Board of Education. The honor recognizes schools across the commonwealth for high student achievement or continuous improvement under the board's new school recognition program.

Four other HCPS were also recognized with the honor in June:

• Colonial Trail Elementary School
• Nuckols Farm Elementary School
• Rivers Edge Elementary School
• Twin Hickory Elementary School

"The awards recognize schools that are exceeding state accreditation standards and schools that are making continuous improvement in improving outcomes for students and in narrowing achievement gaps," said Daniel Gecker, Virginia Board of Education president.

Way to go SES, CTES, NFES, REES and THES!

post_text:
WHAT A MOMENT: After running 3.1 miles, Kaila Corprew and Madison Cunningham of Highland Springs High School saw a Douglas S. Freeman High School runner in need, and together, they would get her across the finish line.

At Wednesday’s Cross Country meet, DSF’s Chloe Ellen fell and was injured. Kaila and Madison, who had just finished their race, went back on the course and picked Chloe up.

Paige Berry, who sent us this photo, said, “The kindness of these two girls shows the compassion that they chose to extend to a fellow racer in need, regardless of team color. They were an amazing example to all of us watching at the finish line. It was truly a privilege to be there!”

Kaila, Madison and Chloe…you make all of Henrico County proud!

post_text:
What should Henrico Schools look like in 2025? Henrico County Public Schools wants to know your views on a new draft version of its proposed guiding document. The Henrico School Board will hold a public hearing Sept. 26 at 5:30 p.m. at New Bridge Learning Center to hear from the public about the updated 2018-25 HCPS Strategic Plan. The hearing will follow the Board’s regularly scheduled work session.

The proposed document more closely aligns the plan to the action items in “Amy’s Passport,” a document created by Amy Cashwell, HCPS superintendent, that contains recommendations for the school division.

Read the latest draft of the proposed 2018-25 HCPS Strategic Plan at henricoschools.us/strategic-plan/.
The “Amy’s Passport” recommendations and a progress report can be found at henricoschools.us/amyspassport/.

A decision on the revised HCPS Strategic Plan is expected in October.

Strategic Plan Public Hearing:
When: Sept. 26 at 5:30 p.m.
Where: New Bridge Learning Center auditorium, 5915 Nine Mile Road, Henrico, Va. 23223
